Erik Wilde (@dret): API Products and API Product Management

(2) Summary

APIs are interfaces providing access to capabilities. As such, an API is just one way to make a capability accessible, but in today's increasingly digital world, they are of course a very important way. For the consumer, an API and the capability it represents are almost the same, and therefore it makes sense to talk about "API products" when referring not just to the technical API, but also to the capability that it represents. Managing API products is an important aspect of a successful API strategy and sustainable API management. As a starting point, it makes sense to consider the traditional "product marketing mix" and its 4 Ps, which are product, price, place, and promotion. The very same model can be applied to API products, only that they have a slightly different set of constraints than traditional products. We look at the key properties of API products, and how they influence the model of product, price, place, and promotion. We also look at how API product management helps to achieve the underlying goal of many API initiatives, which is to move IT from monolithic integrated models to a decentralized ecosystem.

(9) API Products are Products

  • Products have consumers and should drive organizational value
  • API Products are a special kind of product with additional constraints
    • More a service than a (physical) product
    • Many APIs are not (directly) consumed by external consumers
    • API products are the parts for composing digital value chains

API Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): API Products and API Product Management

(17) Product Marketing Mix: 4 Ps

  • Framework for decision-making for product marketing
    • Product: Good or service wanted by consumers
    • Price: What are consumers willing to pay for the product?
    • Place: How to make products available to consumers
    • Promotion: How to make consumers aware of products


API Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): API Products and API Product Management

(18) Expanded Product Marketing Mix: 7 Ps

  • Extends the 4 Ps [Product Marketing Mix: 4 Ps (1)] with a focus on services
  • Framework for decision-making for services marketing
    • People: Considerations regarding service consumers (UX/CX)
    • Process: Planning and managing service delivery
    • Physical Evidence: (Physical) context of service delivery


API Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): API Products and API Product Management

(19) Managing API Change

  • Robust extensibility [http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/2016/04/robust-extensibility.html] helps to facilitate non-breaking API changes
  • The Hypermedia Style [The Five API Styles; Hypermedia Style (1)] helps to move extensibility beyond data models
  • Semantic versioning [http://semver.org/] can be used to keep track of API changes
  • HTTP Deprecation [https://goodapi.co/insights/deprecation-and-sunsetting] can be used to declare APIs as deprecated [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-header/Deprecation]
  • HTTP Sunset [https://goodapi.co/insights/deprecation-and-sunsetting] can be used to signal upcoming sunsets [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-header/Sunset]


API Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): API Products and API Product Management

(20) Semantic Versioning [http://semver.org/]

  • Semantic Versioning [http://semver.org/] standardizes the meaning of version numbers
  • Version numbers use MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH syntax and have well-defined semantics
    • Increase MAJOR version for incompatible API changes
    • Increase MINOR version for adding functionality in a backwards-compatible manner
    • Increase PATCH version for making backwards-compatible bug fixes
  • Mostly about how to name implementation artifacts but also applicable to APIs
    • Exposing detailed version/patch information is a potential security risk
    • For well-designed APIs only MINOR may make sense to expose


API Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): API Products and API Product Management

(21) API Deprecation: Nearing End-of-Life

  • APIs can still be functional but not recommended anymore
  • Explicit API deprecation allows API consumers to look for alternatives
  • The HTTP Deprecation header field [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-header/Sunset] signals API deprecation


API Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): API Products and API Product Management

(22) API Sunset: Reaching End-of-Life

  • APIs will be shut down and consumers should have time to plan for it
  • Explicit API sunset allows API consumers to look for alternatives
  • The HTTP Sunset header field [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-header/Sunset] signals API end-of-life

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): API Products and API Product Management

(24) API Product Management

  • API Products are products like any other product
  • Always think about API consumers and API value
  • Define and manage the product lifecycle of your APIs


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): API Products and API Product Management
